```$ ./canton-templating.py --help
usage: canton-templating.py [-h] [--debug] [--alias-prefix] [--use-gitignore] src_dir dest_dir env_file

Process templates with environment variables, Chart.yaml aliases, symlinks, and .gitignore.

positional arguments:
  src_dir          Source directory containing templates
  dest_dir         Destination directory for processed templates
  env_file         File containing environment variables

options:
  -h, --help       show this help message and exit
  --debug          Enable debug logging for string substitutions
  --alias-prefix   Enable alias prefixing and reindentation in YAML files
  --use-gitignore  Update the Git repository's .gitignore instead of creating one in dest_dir

Mandatory arguments:
  src_dir             Source directory containing templates
  dest_dir            Destination directory for processed templates
  env_file            File containing environment variables

Optional arguments:
  -h, --help          Show this help message and exit
  --debug             Enable debug logging for string substitutions (default: False)
  --alias-prefix      Enable alias prefixing and reindentation in YAML files (default: False)
  --use-gitignore     Update the Git repository's .gitignore instead of creating one in dest_dir (default: False)```

text:
For reference, here is how we do it. Note that what you're doing with the Migration ID to automate it is currently marked as "TODO" for us :sweat_smile:

And it is specific to google cloud

elements.text: For reference, here is how we do it. Note that what you're doing with the Migration ID to automate it is currently marked as "TODO" for us
And it is specific to google cloud

text:
## Upgrading node to a new migration or splice version

1. Preparing changes on your local working machine:

```bash
# read the current splice image tag version from the mainnet info
export NEW_IMAGE_TAG=$(curl -s <https://docs.global.canton.network.sync.global/info> | jq -r '.sv.version')
echo "Got NEW_IMAGE_TAG: $NEW_IMAGE_TAG"

# read the current migration ID from the mainnet info
export NEW_MIGRATION_ID=$(curl -s <https://docs.global.canton.network.sync.global/info> | jq -r '.sv.migration_id')
echo "Got NEW_MIGRATION_ID: $NEW_MIGRATION_ID"

cd ~/git/canton-node/kubernetes-node/mainnet/

# download the file using the current version
echo "Download current splice version"
curl -LO "<https://github.com/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/releases/download/v${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}/${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}_splice-node.tar.gz>"

# backup the current splice-node folder
echo "Backing up current splice-node folder into ~/git/splice-node-backup-before-${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}-migration-$NEW_MIGRATION_ID"
mkdir -p ~/git/splice-node-backups
mv splice-node ~/git/splice-node-backups/splice-node-mainnet-backup-before-${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}-migration-$NEW_MIGRATION_ID

# extract the downloaded file to the current folder (it will extract the new version of splice-node)
echo "extracting downloaded splice file into the splice-node folder:"
tar -xzf ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}_splice-node.tar.gz && echo "Extraction complete."

echo "deleting the downloaded splice file"
rm ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}_splice-node.tar.gz```
At this point, MANUALLY REVIEW the changes on your git client, mostly to check if there are new variables because the values should mostly remain the same, except for the versions.

Probably the main operation will be discarding changes to these key files. Most likely the files are:

• splice-node/examples/sv-helm/participant-values.yaml
• splice-node/examples/sv-helm/scan-values.yaml
• splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-participant-values.yaml
• splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-validator-values.yaml
• splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-cluster-ingress-values.yaml
• splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-values.yaml

TODO: commands to update the MigrationID in the key files, if there is a new Migration ID avaialble

Finally commit and push changes.

2. Connect to the T-RIZE VPN if you are not connected yet.

3. Pushing new version to the cloud:

```bash
# check current migration by visiting <https://sync.global/sv-network/> or directly <https://docs.global.canton.network.sync.global/info>

gcloud auth login

export CLUSTER_NAME="canton-mainnet"
export GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT_NAME="canton-mainnet-validator"
export MIGRATION_ID="2" # updated on 2025-02-24, get current on <https://sync.global/sv-network/>

# switch to the project:
gcloud config set project $GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT_NAME

# connect to gcloud to manage the cluster:
gcloud container clusters get-credentials $CLUSTER_NAME --region us-central1 --project $GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT_NAME


# the dump file is created automatically by the network when it pauses for a migration upgrade.
# Check if it exists with:
kubectl exec -it -n validator deployment/validator-app -- /bin/bash
ll /domain-upgrade-dump/domain_migration_dump.json
# -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17126888 Oct 16 13:01 /domain-upgrade-dump/domain_migration_dump.json
# -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 20794868 Dec 16 17:07 /domain-upgrade-dump/domain_migration_dump.json
# exit using ctrl+d or type:
exit

# update helm to the latest
helm repo update

cd ~/git/canton-node/kubernetes-node/mainnet/

helm upgrade participant <oci://ghcr.io/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/helm/splice-participant> -n validator --version ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG} -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/participant-values.yaml -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-participant-values.yaml --wait
sleep 60
helm upgrade validator <oci://ghcr.io/digital-asset/decentralized-canton-sync/helm/splice-validator> -n validator --version ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG} -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-values.yaml -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-validator-values.yaml --wait

# inspect the state of the cluster and observe pods running in the new namespace:
kubectl get pods -n validator

# how to read logs:
export PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=participant -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export VALIDATOR_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=validator-app -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export WALLET_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=wallet-web-ui -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=utility-ui -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export CNS_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=ans-web-ui -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export POSTGRES_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=postgres -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')

kubectl logs $PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME -n validator -c participant
kubectl describe pod $PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $VALIDATOR_POD_NAME -n validator -c validator-app
kubectl describe pod $VALIDATOR_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $WALLET_POD_NAME -n validator -c wallet-web-ui
kubectl describe pod $WALLET_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME -n validator -c utility-ui
kubectl describe pod $UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $CNS_POD_NAME -n validator -c ans-web-ui
kubectl describe pod $CNS_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $POSTGRES_POD_NAME -n validator -c postgres
kubectl describe pod $POSTGRES_POD_NAME -n validator

# save all logs to /tmp :
DATE=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M")
kubectl logs $PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME -n validator -c participant > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_participant_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $VALIDATOR_POD_NAME -n validator -c validator-app > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_validator-app_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $WALLET_POD_NAME -n validator -c wallet-web-ui > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_wallet-web-ui_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME -n validator -c utility-ui > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_utility-ui_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $CNS_POD_NAME -n validator -c ans-web-ui > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_ans-web-ui_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $POSTGRES_POD_NAME -n validator -c postgres > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_postgres_pod_$DATE.log```

elements.text:
## Upgrading node to a new migration or splice version

1. Preparing changes on your local working machine:

bash
# read the current splice image tag version from the mainnet info
export NEW_IMAGE_TAG=$(curl -s

| jq -r '.sv.version')
echo "Got NEW_IMAGE_TAG: $NEW_IMAGE_TAG"

# read the current migration ID from the mainnet info
export NEW_MIGRATION_ID=$(curl -s

| jq -r '.sv.migration_id')
echo "Got NEW_MIGRATION_ID: $NEW_MIGRATION_ID"

cd ~/git/canton-node/kubernetes-node/mainnet/

# download the file using the current version
echo "Download current splice version"
curl -LO "

"

# backup the current splice-node folder
echo "Backing up current splice-node folder into ~/git/splice-node-backup-before-${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}-migration-$NEW_MIGRATION_ID"
mkdir -p ~/git/splice-node-backups
mv splice-node ~/git/splice-node-backups/splice-node-mainnet-backup-before-${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}-migration-$NEW_MIGRATION_ID

# extract the downloaded file to the current folder (it will extract the new version of splice-node)
echo "extracting downloaded splice file into the splice-node folder:"
tar -xzf ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}_splice-node.tar.gz && echo "Extraction complete."

echo "deleting the downloaded splice file"
rm ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG}_splice-node.tar.gz

At this point, MANUALLY REVIEW the changes on your git client, mostly to check if there are new variables because the values should mostly remain the same, except for the versions.

Probably the main operation will be discarding changes to these key files. Most likely the files are:
splice-node/examples/sv-helm/participant-values.yaml
splice-node/examples/sv-helm/scan-values.yaml
splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-participant-values.yaml
splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-validator-values.yaml
splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-cluster-ingress-values.yaml
splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-values.yaml

TODO: commands to update the MigrationID in the key files, if there is a new Migration ID avaialble

Finally commit and push changes.

2. Connect to the T-RIZE VPN if you are not connected yet.

3. Pushing new version to the cloud:

bash
# check current migration by visiting
or directly

gcloud auth login

export CLUSTER_NAME="canton-mainnet"
export GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT_NAME="canton-mainnet-validator"
export MIGRATION_ID="2" # updated on 2025-02-24, get current on

# switch to the project:
gcloud config set project $GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT_NAME

# connect to gcloud to manage the cluster:
gcloud container clusters get-credentials $CLUSTER_NAME --region us-central1 --project $GOOGLE_CLOUD_PROJECT_NAME


# the dump file is created automatically by the network when it pauses for a migration upgrade.
# Check if it exists with:
kubectl exec -it -n validator deployment/validator-app -- /bin/bash
ll /domain-upgrade-dump/domain_migration_dump.json
# -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 17126888 Oct 16 13:01 /domain-upgrade-dump/domain_migration_dump.json
# -rw-r--r-- 1 root root 20794868 Dec 16 17:07 /domain-upgrade-dump/domain_migration_dump.json
# exit using ctrl+d or type:
exit

# update helm to the latest
helm repo update

cd ~/git/canton-node/kubernetes-node/mainnet/

helm upgrade participant

-n validator --version ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG} -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/participant-values.yaml -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-participant-values.yaml --wait
sleep 60
helm upgrade validator

-n validator --version ${NEW_IMAGE_TAG} -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/validator-values.yaml -f splice-node/examples/sv-helm/standalone-validator-values.yaml --wait

# inspect the state of the cluster and observe pods running in the new namespace:
kubectl get pods -n validator

# how to read logs:
export PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=participant -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export VALIDATOR_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=validator-app -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export WALLET_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=wallet-web-ui -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=utility-ui -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export CNS_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=ans-web-ui -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')
export POSTGRES_POD_NAME=$(kubectl get pods -n validator -l app=postgres -o jsonpath='{.items[0].metadata.name}')

kubectl logs $PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME -n validator -c participant
kubectl describe pod $PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $VALIDATOR_POD_NAME -n validator -c validator-app
kubectl describe pod $VALIDATOR_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $WALLET_POD_NAME -n validator -c wallet-web-ui
kubectl describe pod $WALLET_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME -n validator -c utility-ui
kubectl describe pod $UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $CNS_POD_NAME -n validator -c ans-web-ui
kubectl describe pod $CNS_POD_NAME -n validator

kubectl logs $POSTGRES_POD_NAME -n validator -c postgres
kubectl describe pod $POSTGRES_POD_NAME -n validator

# save all logs to /tmp :
DATE=$(date +"%Y-%m-%d_%H-%M")
kubectl logs $PARTICIPANT_POD_NAME -n validator -c participant > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_participant_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $VALIDATOR_POD_NAME -n validator -c validator-app > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_validator-app_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $WALLET_POD_NAME -n validator -c wallet-web-ui > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_wallet-web-ui_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $UTILITY_UI_POD_NAME -n validator -c utility-ui > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_utility-ui_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $CNS_POD_NAME -n validator -c ans-web-ui > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_ans-web-ui_pod_$DATE.log
kubectl logs $POSTGRES_POD_NAME -n validator -c postgres > /tmp/T-RIZE_mainnet_postgres_pod_$DATE.log

text: I'll release mine proper on monday I suppose. Got to create a public git repo + README + sample

text:
nice Stef and Eduardo.

it's really interesting, we did same approach before moving to terraform. we used <https://docs.gomplate.ca/>

At each deployment we will do

```VERSION=
MIGRATION_ID=
MIGRATING=true/false

gomplate --input-dir=../../helm-tmpl --output-dir=helm-$(MIGRATION_ID)```
Then it will generate helm-value . then we can diff between previous and this one for sanity check.

but eventually we move to terraform module that more or less do the samething with <https://registry.terraform.io/providers/hashicorp/helm/latest/docs>

text: I'm not sure I want to touch HCL anymore. But is gotemplating any better ? ;) I just wanted to keep Helm repo manageable with possibly 3 validators to update every week and possibly soon 3 SV. To apply everything we use a Helm wrapper that can install/update/delete, show diffs and we use it in our CI too. I deployed my 2 docker based Validator via ansible, then I did deploy my 3 k8s based duplicating things and changing by hand but I started working on SV deployment, I didn't want to continue this way

text:
i like gomplate a lot. super easy to install, just a binary to download. update 3 value and re-gen. 

it is flexible enough to support if and loop so we can merged 3 envs into one template.

it supports for loop so we can do stuff like split this string by comma and generate multiple lines such as the admin wallet user

text:
From my README :
```Part of that script could go away/be simplified if a few things were changed in splice provided example values.yaml files :
*   hardcoded values like svNamespace: "sv" or svNamespace: "validator"
*   variables with no values (even a PLACE_HOLDER) that only contains a comment like # Please provide a value as provided in the docs
*   2 blocks, 1 to uncomment depending on network (for sv, nodeId, publicKey, keyAddress)

For the second one, a file containing amuletName, amuletNameAcronym, ... or simply adding fake place-holders like other variables (AMULET_NAME_ACRONYM, ...)

For the third one, 2 files, one containing devnet/testnet values or simply adding fake place-holders like other variables (SV_NODE_ID, SV_PUBLIC_KEY, ...)```

elements.text: From my README :

Part of that script could go away/be simplified if a few things were changed in splice provided example values.yaml files :
*   hardcoded values like svNamespace: "sv" or svNamespace: "validator"
*   variables with no values (even a PLACE_HOLDER) that only contains a comment like # Please provide a value as provided in the docs
*   2 blocks, 1 to uncomment depending on network (for sv, nodeId, publicKey, keyAddress)

For the second one, a file containing amuletName, amuletNameAcronym, ... or simply adding fake place-holders like other variables (AMULET_NAME_ACRONYM, ...)

For the third one, 2 files, one containing devnet/testnet values or simply adding fake place-holders like other variables (SV_NODE_ID, SV_PUBLIC_KEY, ...)
